questions.title: Enter the amount of National Insurance you paid from a recent payslip
questions.derivation: Use a payslip dated after 12 April 2023 to answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount of National Insurance you paid</br></br>You can usually find the amount next to any pensions or PAYE/Income Tax deductions on your payslip.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds and pence, exactly as it appears on your payslip.

questions.title: Enter the amount of Income Tax you paid from a recent payslip
questions.derivation: Use a payslip dated after 12 April 2023 to help you answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount of Income Tax you paid.</br></br>You can usually find the amount next to any pensions or National Insurance payments on your payslip. It may be called PAYE/Income Tax.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds and pence, exactly as it appears on your payslip.

questions.title: Enter the last 4 digits of the bank or building society account your tax credits are paid into
questions.instructionsParagraph: You can look for your account number on your:
questions.instructions:
• bank card
  • online account or banking app
  • bank statemen
  • paying-in book or cheque book

formCode.heading: Last 4 digits of your account number

questions.title: Enter a recent tax credits payment amount
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us about a tax credits payment you’ve had after 12 April 2023.</br></br>You’ll get tax credits payments every week or every 4 weeks. You only need to enter one payment amount.

questions.title: What type of Self Assessment tax return did you send for the tax year 2021 to 2022?
questions.instructionsParagraph: This is so we can ask you questions about the right Self Assessment tax return.</br></br>You’ll only have sent a short tax return (SA200) if HMRC told you to.

questions.title: Enter pensions and benefits amounts from your Self Assessment tax return
questions.derivation: Use your Self Assessment tax return for the tax year 2022 to 2023 to answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount of pensions and benefits you received.</br></br>The box numbers and names on this page are the same as on your tax return.</br></br>Enter the amounts in pounds without the pence, exactly as they appear on your tax return. If the box in your tax return is empty, enter 0.

formFields.name: box-11
formFields.labelText: Pensions (other than State Pensions), retirement annuities and taxable lump sums treated as pensions

formFields.name: box-13
formFields.labelText: Taxable Incapacity Benefit and contribution-based Employment and Support Allowance

formFields.name: box-16
formFields.labelText: Total of any other taxable State Pensions and benefits

questions.title: Enter pensions and benefits amounts from your short tax return
questions.derivation: Use your short tax return (SA200) for the tax year 2022 to 2023 to answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amounts you received in pensions and benefits.</br></br>The box numbers and names on this page are the same as on your tax return.</br></br>Enter the amounts in pounds without the pence, exactly as they appear on your tax return. If the box on your tax return is empty, enter 0.
questions.instructions:
• Use a Self Assessment tax return from 2021 to 2022
  • These figures are whole pounds and do not include pence. Enter the exact amount not including pence, for example 923
  • If a pension or benefit does not apply to you, enter 0

formFields.name: box-4-2
formFields.labelText: Pensions (other than State Pensions), retirement annuities and taxable lump sums treated as pensions

formFields.name: box-4-3
formFields.labelText: Taxable Incapacity Benefit and contribution-based Employment and Support Allowance (ESA)

formFields.name: box-4-6
formFields.labelText: Total of any other taxable State Pensions and benefits

questions.title: Enter the details of your most recent Self Assessment payment
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount of National Insurance you paid</br></br>You can usually find the amount next to any pensions or PAYE/Income Tax deductions on your payslip.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds and pence, exactly as it appears on your payslip.
questions.instructions:
• These must be the details of a payment made to HMRC, not information from a Self Assessment return
  • You can get this information from your bank account
  • Enter the date the payment left your account, and the exact amount of the payment, including pence

formCode.heading: Payment Amount
formCode.preCustomHtml:
Date of payment

For example, 31 3 2020

questions.title: Enter the ‘employee’s contributions’ amount from your P60
questions.derivation: Use your P60 from the tax year 2022 to 2023 to answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount in the box labelled ‘employee’s contributions due on all earnings above the PT’.  You’ll find this in the ‘National Insurance contributions for this employment’ section of your P60.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds and pence, exactly as it appears on your P60.

questions.title: Enter the ‘total for year’ amount from your P60
questions.derivation: Use your P60 from the tax year 2022 to 2023 to answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount in the box labelled ‘total for year’. You’ll find this in the ‘pay and Income Tax details’ section of your P60.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds and pence, exactly as it appears on your P60.

questions.title: Enter the ‘earnings above the PT’ amount from your P60
questions.derivation: Use your P60 from the tax year 2022 to 2023 to answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount in the box labelled ‘earnings above the PT, up to and including the Upper Earnings Limit (UEL)’. You’ll find this in the section of your P60 called ‘National Insurance contributions in this employment’.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds without the pence, exactly as it appears on your P60.
questions.instructions:
• Use a P60 from the financial year 2022 to 2023.
  • Get the figure from the ‘Earnings above the PT, up to and including the Upper Earnings Limit (UEL)’ column.
  • Enter the figure exactly, not including pence.

postQuestionDetails.summaryText: Where to find this amount on a P60

questions.title: Enter the ‘postgraduate loan deductions’ amount from your P60
questions.derivation: Use your P60 from the tax year 2022 to 2023 to answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount in the box labelled ‘postgraduate loan deductions.’ You’ll find this in the ‘other details’ section of your P60.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds without the pence, exactly as it appears on your P60.

questions.title: Enter the ‘statutory shared parental pay’ amount from your P60
questions.derivation: Use your P60 from the tax year 2022 to 2023 to answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount in the box labelled ‘statutory shared parental pay.’ You’ll find this in the ‘statutory payments’ section of your P60.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds and pence, exactly as it appears on your P60.

questions.title: Enter the ‘Statutory Adoption Pay’ figure on your P60
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount in the box labelled ‘statutory adoption pay.’ You’ll find this in the ‘statutory payments’ section of your P60.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds and pence, exactly as it appears on your P60.

questions.title: Enter the ‘statutory maternity pay’ amount from your P60
questions.derivation: Enter the ‘statutory maternity pay’ amount from your P60
questions.instructionsParagraph: Tell us the amount in the box labelled ‘statutory maternity pay.’ You’ll find this in the ‘statutory payments’ section of your P60.</br></br>Enter the amount in pounds and pence, exactly as it appears on your P60.

questions.title: Enter the ‘student loan deductions’ amount from your P60
questions.derivation: Use your P60 from the tax year 2022 to 2023 to answer this question.
questions.instructionsParagraph: TTell us the amount in the box labelled ‘student loan deductions.’ You’ll find this in the ‘other details’ section of your P60.</br></br>YEnter the amount in pounds without the pence, exactly as it appears on your P60.
